sp.p: These are pretences. But I'll come, however, on one condition.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: That you allow me to be gone to-morrow, without endeavouring to detain me.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Go! Whither?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: No matter ! Promise this, or I will not come.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Well, I do promise.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I have directions to give my servant.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: In half an hour, then, we shall expect you. Remember, you have given your word.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I have. Exit Baron, C. and L. (walks up and down, thoughtful and melancholy) Francis ! Francis!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I shall leave this place to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Perhaps to go into another land.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With all my heart again !

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Perhaps into another quarter of the globe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With all my heart still. Into which quarter ?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Wherever heaven directs! Away! away ! from Europe — from this cultivated moral lazaret! Do you hear, Francis ? To-morrow, early !

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: But first I have an errand for you. Hire that carnage in the village ; drive to the town hard by: you may be back by sunset. I shall give you a letter to a. widow who lives there. With her you will find two children. They are mine.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: (astonished) Your children, sir!

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Take them, and bring them hither.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your children, sir!

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Yes, mine ! Is it so very inconceivable ?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That I should have been three years in your service, and never have heard them mentioned, is somewhat strange.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Pshaw!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You have been married, then ?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Go, and prepare for our journey.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That I can do in five minutes.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I shall come and write the letter directly. Yes, I'll take them with me. I'll accustom myself to the sight of them. The innocents! they shall not be poisoned by the refinements of society. Rather let them hunt their daily sustenance upon some desert island, with their bow and arrow; or creep like torpid Hottentots into a corner, and stare at each other. Better to do nothing, than to do evil. Fool that I was, to be prevailed upon once more to exhibit myself among these apes! What a ridiculous figure shall I be, and in the capacity of a suitor, too! Pshaw, he cannot be serious! 'Tis but a friendly artifice, to draw me from my solitude. Why did I promise him ? Well, my sufferings have been many; and, to oblige a friend, why should I not add another painful hour to the wretched calendar of my life ? I'll go ! I'll go !

div.head: Scene II. The Ante-chamber.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: No, indeed, my lady ! If you choose to bury yourself in the country, I shall take my leave. I am not calculated for country life. And, to sum up all, when I think of this Mrs. Haller——

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: (overhearing her last words) What of Mrs. Haller, my sweet miss ?

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Solomon, who is Mrs. Haller ? You know everything; you hear everything.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: I have received no letters from any part of Europe on the subject, miss.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: But who is to blame? The Count and Countess. She dines with them, and, at this very moment, is drinking tea with them. Is this proper ?

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: Shouldn't a Count, in all his actions, show a certain degree of pride and pomposity?

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: To be sure ! To be sure he should!

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: No, I won't submit to it. I'll tell her ladyship, when I dress her to-morrow, that either Mrs. Haller, or I must quit the house.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: (seeing the Baron) —St!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Didn't I hear Mrs. Haller's name here ?

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: (confused) Why — yes — we — we ——

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Charlotte, tell my sister I wish to see her as soon as the tea table is removed. (goes up)

sp.speaker: Charl.
sp.p: (aside to Solomon) Either she or I go, that I'm determined.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (L.C.) May I ask what it was you were saying ?

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: Why, please your Honourable Lordship, we were talking here and there — this and that ——

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I almost begin to suspect some secret.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: Secret! Heaven forbid! Mercy on us! No ! I should have had letters on the subject, if there had been a secret.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Well then, since it was no secret, I presume I may know your conversation.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: You do us great honor, my lord. Why, then, at first, we were making a few commonplace observations. Miss Charlotte remarked that we all had our faults. I said " Yes." Soon after I remarked that the best persons in the world were not without their weaknesses. She said "Yes."

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: If you referred to Mrs. Haller's faults and weaknesses, I am desirous to hear more.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: Sure enough, sir, Mrs. Haller is an excellent woman; but she is not an angel, for all that. I am an old, faithful servant, to his Excellency, the Count, and therefore it is my duty to speak, when anything is done disadvantageous to his interest.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: For instance, now; his Excellency may think he has, at least, some score of dozens of the old six-and- twenty hock. Mercy on us! there are not ten dozen bottles left; and not a drop has gone down my throat, I'll swear.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: (smiling) Mrs. Haller has not drank it, I suppose?

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: Not she herself, for she never drinks wine. But if anybody be ill in the village — any poor woman lying-in, that might think herself well off with common Rhenish, — away goes a bottle of the six-and-twenty ! Innumerable are the times that I've reproved her; but she always answers me snappishly, that she will be responsible for it.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: So will I, Mr. Solomon.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: Oh ! with all my heart, your Honourable Lordship. It makes no difference to me. I had the care of the cellar twenty years, and can safely take my oath, that I never gave the poor a single drop in the whole course of my trust.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: How extraordinary is this woman !

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: Extraordinary! One can make nothing of her. To-day, the vicar's wife is not good enough for her; — to-morrow, you may see her sitting with all the women of the village. To be sure, she and I agree pretty well; for, between me and your Honourable Lordship, she has cast an eye upon my son Peter.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Has she ?

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: Yes; Peter's no fool, I assure you. The schoolmaster is teaching him to write. Would your Honourable Lordship please to see a specimen? I'll go for his copy-book. He makes his pot-hooks capitally.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Another time — another time. Good-bye for the present, Mr. Solomon. (crosses to R., Solomon bows without attempting to go) Good day, Mr. Solomon !

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: (not understanding the hint) Your Honourable Lordship's most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: This is too bad. Mr. Solomon, I wish to be alone.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: As your lordship commands. If the time should seem long in my absence, and your lordship wishes to hear the newest news from the seat of war, you need only send for old Solomon. I have letters from Leghorn, Cape Horn, and every known part of the habitable globe.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Tedious old fool! Yet hold. Did he not speak in praise of Mrs. Haller ? Pardoned be his rage for news and politics.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Well sister, have you spoken to her?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I have : and if you do not steer for another haven, you will be doomed to drive upon the ocean for ever.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Is she married ?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Is she of good family ?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Does she dislike me ?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Excuse my making a reply.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I thank you for your sisterly affection, and the explicitness of your communications. Luckily, I placed little reliance on either, and have found a friend who will save your ladyship all further trouble.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: A friend!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Yes. The Stranger, who saved your son's life this morning, proves to be my intimate friend.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: What's his name ?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I don't know.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Is he of good family ?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Will he come hither?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Excuse my making a reply.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Well, the retort is fair, but insufferable.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: You can't object to the da capo of your own composition.

div.stage: Enter Count and Mrs. Haller, R.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Zounds! do you think I am Xenocrates; or like the poor Sultan with marble legs ? There you leave me tête-a-tête with Mrs. Haller, as if my heart were a mere flint. So you prevailed, brother ? The Stranger will come then, it seems.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I expect him every minute.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I'm glad to hear it: one companion more, how ever. In the country we never can have too many.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: This gentleman will not exactly be an addition to your circle, for he leaves this place to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: But he won't, I think. Now, Lady Wintersen, summon all your charms. There is no art in conquering us poor devils ; but this strange man, who does not care a doit for you altogether, is worth your efforts. Try your skill. I shan't be jealous.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: I allow the conquest to be worth the trouble. But, what Mrs. Haller has not been able to effect in three months, ought not to be attempted by me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: (jocosely) O yes, madam ; he has given me no opportunity of trying the force of my charms, for I have never once happened to see him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then he's a blockhead, and you an idler.

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: (without) This way, sir ! this way !

sp.speaker: Solom.
sp.p: The Stranger begs leave to have the honor——

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Welcome ! welcome ! Show him the way.

div.stage: (turns to meet the Stranger, whom he takes by the hand) My dear sir — Lady Wintersen — Mrs. Haller. (introducing him)
Mrs. Haller as soon as she sees the Stranger, shrieks and swoons in the arms of the Baron and Countess.
The Stranger casts a look at her, and struck with astonishment and horror, rushes out of the room, L. The Baron and Countess supporting Mrs. Haller, Count standing motionless in great surprise.

div.head: Scene I.--The Ante-chamber.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Oh, deceitful hope! Thou phantom of future happiness! To thee have I stretched out my arms, and thou hast vanished into air! Wretched Steinfort! The mystery is solved—she is the wife of my friend! I cannot myself be happy, but I may, perhaps, be able to re-unite two noble hearts, whom cruel fate has severed. Ha! they are here; I must propose it instantly.

div.stage: Enter Countess and Mrs. Haller, R.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Into the garden, my dear friend; into the air!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I am quite well. Do not alarm yourselves on my account.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Madam, pardon my intrusion, but to lose a moment may be fatal: he means to quit the country to- morrow. We must devise means to reconcile you to—the Stranger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: How, my lord? You seem acquainted with my history!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: I am. Waldbourg has been my friend ever since we were boys. We served together from the rank of cadet. We have been separated seven years: chance brought us this day together, and his heart was open to me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Now do I feel what it is to be in the presence of an honest man, when I dare not meet his eye. (hides her face)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: If sincere repentance—if years without reproach do not give us a title to man's forgiveness, what must we expect hereafter? No, lovely penitent! your contrition is complete. Error, for a moment, wrested from slumbering virtue the dominion of your heart; but she awoke, and, with a look, banished her enemy for ever. I know my friend: he has the firmness of a man; but with it, the gentlest feelings of your sex. I hasten to him. (going)

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh, stay! What would you do? No, never! My husband's honor is sacred to me. I love him un- utterably, but never, never can I be his wife again; even if he were generous enough to pardon me.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Madam! Can you, Countess, be serious?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Not that title, I beseech you! I am not a child, who wishes to avoid deserved punishment. What were my penitence, if I hoped advantage from it, beyond the consciousness of atonement for past offence?

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: But if your husband himself—

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh! he will not! he cannot! And let him rest assured, I never would replace my honor at the expense of his.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: He still loves you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Loves me! Then he must not—No! he must purify his heart from a weakness which would de- grade him.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Incomparable woman! I go to my friend— perhaps for the last time. Have you not one word to send him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Yes; I have two requests to make. Often, when, in excess of grief, I have despaired of every con- solation, I have thought I should be easier if I might behold my husband once again, acknowledge my injustice to him, and take a gentle leave of him for ever. This, therefore, is my first request—a conversation for a few short minutes, if he does not quite abhor the sight of me. My second request is—Oh!—not to see, but to hear some account of my poor children.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p:
If humanity and friendship can avail, he will not for a moment delay your wishes. With the fire of pure disinterested friendship will I enter on this work; that when I look back upon my past life, I may derive
from this good action consolation in disappointment, and even resignation in despair.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Heaven be with you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: And my prayers.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Come, my friend, come into the air; till he returns with hope and consolation.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh, my heart! how art thou afflicted! My husband! My little ones! Past joys and future fears—Oh, dearest madam! there are moments in which we live years—moments which steal the roses from the cheek of health, and plough deep furrows in the brow of youth.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Banish these sad reflections. Come, let us walk. The sun will set soon; lest nature's beauties dissipate anxiety.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Alas! Yes, the setting sun is a proper scene for me.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.p: Never forget a morning will succeed.

div.head: Scene II. The skirts of the Park, Lodge, &c, as before.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: On earth there is but one such pair. They shall not be parted. Yet what I have undertaken is not so easy as I at first hoped. What can I answer, when he asks me, whether I would persuade him to renounce his character, and become the derision of society?—for he is right—a faithless wife is a dishonor: to forgive her, is to share her shame. What, though Adelaide may be an exception; a young deluded girl, who has so long, and so sincerely repented: yet, what cares an unfeeling world for this? The world!—he has quitted it. 'Tis evident he loves her still, and upon this assurance builds my sanguine heart and hope, of a happy termination to an honest enterprise.

div.stage: Enter Francis, C. from R., with two children, William and Amelia.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Come along, my pretty ones—come!

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Is it far to home?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, we shall be there directly, now.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Hold! Whose children are these?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My master's.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Is that my father?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: It darts like lightning through my brain! A word with you. I know you love your master. Strange things have happened here. Your master has found his wife again.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Indeed! Glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Mrs. Haller—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Is she his wife? Still more glad to hear it.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: But he is determined to go from her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: We must try to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Surely.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: The unexpected appearance of the children may perhaps assist us.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Hide yourself with them in that hut. Before a quarter of an hour is past you shall know more.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: No more questions, I entreat you. Time is precious.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well, well; questions are not much in my way. Come, children.

sp.speaker: Wil.
sp.p: Why, I thought you told me I should see my father?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: So you shall, my dear. Come, moppets.

div.stage: Goes into the hut, L. 3 E., with Children.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Excellent! I promise myself much from this little artifice. If the mild look of the mother fails, the innocent smiles of these his own children will surely find the way to his heart. (taps at the lodge door) Stranger comes out, R. Charles, I wish you joy.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Of what?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: You have found her again.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Show a bankrupt the treasure which he once possessed, and then congratulate him on the amount!

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Why not, if it be in your power to retrieve the whole?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I understand you; you are a negotiator from my wife. It won't avail.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Learn to know your wife better. Yes, I am a messenger from her, but without power to treat. She, who loves you unutterably—who, without you, never can be happy—renounces your forgiveness, because, as she thinks, your honor is incompatible with such a weakness.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Pshaw! I am not to be caught.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Charles! consider well—

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Steinfort, let me explain all this. I have lived here four months. Adelaide knew it.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Knew it! She never saw you till to-day.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: That she may make fools believe. Hear further: she knows too that I am not a common sort of man—that my heart is not to be attacked in the usual way; she, therefore, framed a nice, deep-concerted plan. She played a charitable part; but in such a way, that it always reached my ears—she played a pious, modest, reserved part in order to excite my curiosity; and at last to-day she plays the prude. She refuses my forgiveness in order, by this generous device, to extort it from my compassion.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Charles! I have listened to you with astonishment: this is weakness only to be pardoned in a man who has so often been deceived by the world. Your wife has expressly and steadfastly declared that she will not accept your forgiveness, even if you yourself were weak enough to offer it.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: What, then, has brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: More than one reason. First, I am come in my own name, as your friend and comrade, to conjure you solemnly not to spurn this creature from you—for, by my soul, you will not find her equal.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Give yourself no further trouble.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Be candid, Charles—you love her still?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Alas! yes.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Her sincere repentance has long since obliterated her crime.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Sir! a wife, once induced to forfeit her honor, must be capable of a second crime.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Not so, Charles. Ask your own heart what portion of the blame may be your own.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Mine?

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Yours. Who told you to marry a thoughtless, inexperienced girl? One scarce expects established principles at five-and-twenty in a man, yet you require them in a girl of sixteen! But of this no more. She has erred—she has repented; and, during three years, her conduct has been so far above reproach, that even the piercing eye of Calumny has not discovered a speck upon this radiant orb.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Now, were I to believe all this—for I confess I would willingly believe it—yet can she never again be mine. (with extreme asperity) Oh! what a feast would it be for the painted dolls, when I appeared among them, with my runaway wife upon my arm! What mocking, whispering, and pointing! Never! never! never! (crosses, L.)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: Enough! As a friend I have done my duty— I now appear as Adelaide's ambassador. She requests one moment's conversation; she wishes once again to see you, and never more! You cannot deny her this only, this last request.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Oh! I understand this too. She thinks my firmness will be melted by her tears; she is mistaken— she may come.

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: She will come, to make you feel how much you mistake her. I go for her.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Another word. Give her this paper and these jewels. They belong to her. (presenting them)

sp.speaker: Baron.
sp.p: That you may do yourself.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: The last anxious moment of my life draws near. I shall see her once again; see her on whom my soul doats. Is this the language of an injured husband? Alas! alas! What is the principle which we call honor? Is it a feeling of the heart, or a mere quibble of the brain? I must be resolute: it cannot now be otherwise. Let me speak solemnly, yet mildly; and beware that nothing of reproach escape my lips. Yes, her penitence is real. She shall not be obliged to live in mean dependence; she shall be mistress of herself, and have enough to—
Ha! they come. Awake, insulted pride! Protect me, injured honor!

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Haller, Countess, and Baron, at the gate, C. from L.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: (advances slowly, and with tremor; Countess attempts to support her) Leave me now, I beseech you. Baron and Countess go off to hut, L. 3 E. (approaches Stranger, who with averted countenance, and extreme agitation, awaits her address) My lord!

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (R. C, with gentle tremulous utterance, and face still turned away) What would you with me, Adelaide?

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: (L.C., much agitated) No—for heaven's sake! I was not prepared, for this. Oh! that tone cuts to my heart, —Adelaide! No,—for heaven's sake! Harsh tones alone are suited to a culprit's ear.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (endeavouring to give his voice firmness) Well, madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh! if you will ease my heart, if you will spare and pity me, use reproaches.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Reproaches! Here they are, upon my sallow cheek—here in my hollow eye—here in my faded form. These reproaches I could not spare you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Were I a hardened sinner, this forbearance would be charity; but I am a suffering penitent, and it overpowers me. Alas! then I must be the herald of my own shame: for, where shall I find peace, till I have eased my soul by my confession?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: No confession, madam! I release you from every humiliation. I perceive you feel that we must part for ever.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I know it. Nor come I here to supplicate your pardon; nor has my heart contained a ray of hope that you would grant it. All I dare ask, is, that you will not curse my memory.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (moved) No, Adelaide! I do not curse you. No! I shall never curse you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p:
(agitated) From the inward conviction that I am unworthy of your name, I have, during three years, abandoned it. But that is not enough; you must have
that redress which will enable you to choose another— another wife, in whose untainted arms may heaven protect your hours in bliss! This paper will be necessary for the purpose: it contains a written acknowledgment of my guilt. (offers it trembling)

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (tearing it) Perish the record, for ever! No, Adelaide, you only have possessed my heart; and, without shame, I confess it, you alone will reign there for ever! Your own sensations of virtue, your resolute honor, forbid you to profit by my weakness; and even if—now, by heaven! this is beneath a man! but—never—never—will another fill Adelaide's place here!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: (trembling) Then nothing now remains but that one sad, hard, just word—farewell!

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: A moment stay. For some months we have, without knowing it, lived near each other. I have learnt much good of you. You have a heart open to the wants of your fellow-creatures: I am happy that it is so. You shall not be without the power of gratifying your benevolence. I know you have a spirit that must shrink from a state of obligation. This paper, to which the whole remnant of my fortune is pledged, secures you independence, Adelaide; and let the only recommendation of the gift be, that it will administer to you the means of indulging in charity—the divine propensity of your nature.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Never! By the labour of my hands must I earn my sustenance. A morsel of bread, moistened with the tear of penitence, will suffice my wishes, and exceed my merits. It would be an additional reproach to think that I served myself, or even others, from the bounty of him whom I had so basely injured.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (much affected) Take it, madam, take it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I have deserved this! but I throw myself upon your generosity—have compassion on me!

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (aside) Villain! of what a woman hast thou robbed me! (puts up the paper) Well, madam! I respect your sentiments, and withdraw my request; but on this one condition—that if you ever should be in want of any- thing, I shall be the first and only person in the world to whom you will make application!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: I promise it, my lord!

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: And now I may at least desire you to take back what is your own—your jewels—(gives her the casket)

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: (opens it in violent agitation, her tears falling upon it) How well do I recollect the sweet evening when you gave me these! That evening my father joined our hands; and joyfully I pronounced the oath of eternal fidelity—It is broken! This locket you gave me on my birth-day—'tis five years since. That was a happy day! We had a country feast—how cheerful we all were! This bracelet I received after my William was born! No! I cannot keep these, unless you wish that the sight of them should be an incessant reproach to my almost broken heart. (gives them back)

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (aside) I must go. My soul and pride will hold no longer. Farewell!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Oh! but one minute more! An answer to but one more question! feel for a mother's heart! Are my children still alive?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: They are alive!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: And well?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: They are well.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: Heaven be praised! William must be much grown?

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: I believe so.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: What! have you not seen them? And little Amelia, is she still your favourite? (the Stranger, who is in violent agitation throughout this scene, remains in silent attention between honor and affection) Oh! if you knew how my heart was hung upon them for these three long dreadful years—how I have sat at evening twilight, first fancying William, then Amelia on my lap—oh! allow me to behold them once again—let me once more kiss the creatures of their father and his babes, and I will kneel to you, and part with them for ever.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: Willingly, Adelaide—this very night! I expect the children every minute. They have been brought up near this spot. I have already sent my servant for them. He might before this time have returned. I pledge my word to send them to the castle as soon as they arrive. Here, if you please, they may remain till day-break to- morrow, then they must go with me. (a pause)

div.stage: The Countess and Baron return with Francis and the Children. He gives the Boy to the Countess— who places herself behind Mrs. Haller, he himself walks with the Girl behind the Stranger.

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: In this world, then, we have no more to say. (summoning all her resolution) Farewell! (seizing his hand) Forget a wretch who never will forget you! (kneels) Let me press this hand once more to my lips—this hand, which once was mine.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: (raising her) No humiliation, Adelaide! (shakes her hand) Farewell!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: A last farewell.

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: The last!

sp.speaker: Mrs. H.
sp.p: And when my penance shall have broken my heart, when we again meet in a better world—

sp.speaker: Stran.
sp.p: There, Adelaide, you may be mine again;

div.stage: Their hands lie in each other—their eyes—mournfully meet each other—they stammer another "Farewell!" and part. But as they are going she encounters the Boy, and he the Girl.

sp.speaker: Children.
sp.p: Dear father! Dear mother!

div.stage: They press the Children in their arms with speechless affection; then tear themselves away—gaze at each other—spread their arms, and rush into an embrace. The Children run and cling round their parents. The curtain falls.
Francis. Baron. Amelia. Stran. Mrs. H. William. Countess. R. L.
